Hi again, as a follow on from my last message I would like to explain a 
bit more about what I am doing here and some other ideas that I have.

Some history. I originally got involved in Evolutionary Computing about 
10 years ago. I looked into using EC to find/build timetables for, say, 
schools and universities. At the time others had already looked at this 
domain but had tended to implement searches for very specific types of 
problem. Every time a different type of timetable was looked at (e.g. an 
exam timetable versus a day-to-day one) then a new genome representation 
was devised. I was also frustrated by the use of string based genomes by 
almost all the representations I came across, which basically meant that 
90% of mutations and crossovers where totally meaningless.

I just thought why not build a general genome that can represent all of 
the problems and why not use a genome that is structured so that I can 
devise more meaningful genetic opeatos.  Now as it happens it didn't 
work well enough to be useful, largely due to my inexperience in writing 
robust code at the time. At the same time I was studying Neural Nets for 
a couple of hours a week and I wondered if anyone had tried combining 
NN's and EC.  Well obviously quite a few people had.

Cut to 1996 where I picked up the idea again and wrote an Neuro 
Evolution (NE) system. As an outline this is how it worked...

1) A tree based genome. This helps in a few different ways. When 
crossover occurs we only swap nodes that are co-located on both parents. 
It also allows us to implement a 'reference' node (more later). And it 
allow us to mutate the genome by not only mutating data within a node, 
but by copying, deleting and moving branches of the tree around. By 
relating nodes in a tree and branchies of the tree I thought I would 
facilitate more intelligent, meaningful manipualtion of the genome.

2) Each node either represents a neuron or a reference. Neurons have a 
position, which is relative to the parent node. They also have a list of 
(incoming) connections. Each connection has a length (thus giving a 
position to connect to, relative to the neuron's position) and a 
weight. The networks evolved thus have fixed weights. Also note that 
connections connect to the nearest neuron, therefore the connection 
length does not have to be precise, or even anywhere near a neuron.  
Where a neuron is a child of a reference node there is a highly 
convoluted technique whereby I  evolving a connection point onto the 
parent tree. In theory this allows re-used parts of the tree to be 
extended further (variation on reused genes). In hindsight it is a very 
poor implementation.

3) Reference nodes. A node on the tree that cause traversal to jump to 
some other specified point. The reference itself is just a list of 
numbers, each number is basically a list of child indexes specifying a 
path to the referenced node through the tree starting from the root 
node. Later I also implemented relative references where a child index 
of -1 means to traverse back up the tree one node. Reference nodes allow 
for the possibility of re-use and therefore aid in evolving complexity.

I tried the system on the prey capture problem, but it performed poorly. 
Solving 4, 0.0 (a prey with 4 initial moves, but no speed).


I recently picked up the project again and ported/rewrote it in C#. The 
genome has been completely re-written and has a few more tricks but is 
essentially the same concept. This time I was able to solve prey capture 
properly. I had realised that the original failure was primarily caused 
by a poor inability to search different connection combinations between 
neurons due to poorly implemented genetic operators.

Following all of this I came across NEAT and have read a few recent 
papers from the Computer Science department at  the university of Texas 
which have give me a lot of ideas. Particularly interesting is the 
speciation mechanism used by NEAT.  I recon I can implement this on my 
own NE system by comparing the structure of my tree based genomes and 
generating a compatibilty figure similair to the one Ken has used. 
Meanwhile I will be getting a feel for just how efficient NEAT is at 
solving problems and looking for new test problems I can use.



Colin.
